detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: For 3rd and 4th year undergraduates (see MUSC 164A for 1st and 2nd year registration; MUSC 564A for graduate students).OPEN TO NON-MUSIC STUDENTS: How do I register for ensembles? For most ensembles an audition is required to secure your place. During the audition you play or sing a prepared piece for the conductor. Auditions for ensembles take place at the beginning of each academic year. https://music.ubc.ca/about/student-ensembles/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: CHINESE INSTRUMENTAL ENSEMBLEFor 3rd and 4th year undergraduates (see MUSC 165A for 1st and 2nd year registration; MUSC 565A for graduate students).For most ensembles an audition is required to secure your place. During the audition you play or sing a prepared piece for the conductor. Auditions for ensembles take place at the beginning of each academic year. http://music.ubc.ca/student-ensemblesOPEN TO NON-MUSIC STUDENTS: How do I register for ensembles? Please register in the waitlist for the lower-level version of this ensemble. Youll receive information about the audition process and if youre admitted, well make sure youre in the correct ensemble course code.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: BALINESE GAMELAN ENSEMBLEFor 3rd and 4th year undergraduates (see MUSC 165B for 1st and 2nd year registration; MUSC 565B for graduate students).OPEN TO NON-MUSIC STUDENTS: The gamelan is open to all without audition.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: AFRICAN MUSIC & DANCE ENSEMBLEFor 3rd and 4th year undergraduates (see MUSC 165D for 1st and 2nd year registration; MUSC 565D for graduate students).OPEN TO NON-MUSIC STUDENTS: How do I register for ensembles? The course is open to all without audition.This course/ensemble introduces drumming techniques, dances and other artistic expressions of Africa. Through the instruments, the voice, the dance movements and other visual art forms and paraphernalia, this class/ensemble brings to the stage a unique African theatrical experience. The course/ensemble may be repeated for credit. It will include public performances (concerts and lecture demonstrations). Also as a practical way of preparing for the main concert, students may be requested to participate in other performances on or off campus as the need may arise.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Topic: Sound WritingApproaching the study of sound and poetry this course will introduce students to a range of writing, sound art, and listening practices. We will question how we transcribe/translate our multi-sensory experiences of sound through different forms of writing and will spend time listening together to recordings, readings, and to the land and waterways of this place. We will ask what listening does as we collectively create scenarios and event scores for de-centering listening habits. In addition to listening to recordings we will also listen to each other read, activating our voices, and exploring various interpolations of written form. Through listening prompts, we will practice recognizing/naming/distilling what we hear, thinking of how we might respond to what we hear, and forming creative written and oral/recorded responses that may include poetry, lyric, fiction, auto-theory, performance, and more. The course's procedural work will lend itself to a final project that will include both a written and oral (or audible) component.Restricted to 4thyear undergraduate students and graduate students.Registration by permission of instructor. Contactdylan.w.robinson@ubc.ca

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Restricted to students in BMLS
2024W: 10 general seats are available for students in year 3, 4 or higher who have completed BIOL 260 or CAPS 390 or 391 course AND a second-year level 3 credit CHEM or BIOC course (e.g., BIOL 201, BIOC 202, or BIOC 203). Interested students register in the waitlist; registration will be reviewed/approved by the program coordinator.
This in-person course runs Wednesdays, 9am-11am across Terms 1 and 2. View course information: PATH 407 - Clinical Toxicology 2024W
This course is held in UBC Hospital. Students, staff and faculty are subject to the current Public Health Orders (PHO), which require a) double COVID vaccination and b) verification/declaration of your vaccination status; masks are optional within laboratories and classrooms.

Interested students register in the waitlist; registration will be updated on a first-come basis. View course information: PATH 408 - Research and Career Skills 2024W

This course is held in UBC Hospital. Students, staff and faculty are subject to the current Public Health Orders (PHO), which require a) double COVID vaccination and b) verification/declaration of your vaccination status; masks are optional within laboratories and classrooms.

instances.text: PERS_V 400-011 - Persian Short Story for Native and Heritage Speakers

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous multi-access course. Students are expected to meet on the days and times listed, either in-person or online. All courses labelled multi-access offer students the choice of completing the course online, in-person, or using a mix of both. In-person attendance is NOT required, but the option to attend in-person is available. Lectures may be streamed from a classroom and/or uploaded online after class.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to Waitlist and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

PHAR_V 497-E_001 - Directed Studies in Pharmaceutical Sciences (E)
PHAR_V 497-E_002 - Directed Studies in Pharmaceutical Sciences (E)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Course Description
Four British women philosophers--G. E. M. Anscombe, Philippa Foot, Iris Murdoch, and Mary Midgley--have been credited with changing the direction of moral philosophy in the middle of the 20th century, as two recent popular philosophical books argue. Each of them is an important figure in her own right, but collectively, their work, friendship, and approach to philosophy marked a significant shift in ethical thought, including a revival of interest in Aristotle's ethics and "virtue ethics." This course will look at the philosophical world they were trained in, how they objected and responded to it, and what lasting impacts their work has had. It will also serve as an introduction to some of their most important works as well as the history of mid-20th century analytic philosophy.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: This course willintroduce students to contemporaryphilosophy of perception. Likely topics include:the nature of sensory experience; perceptual knowledge; illusion and hallucination;introspection;andasymmetries between vision and audition. Students will be assessed by a mix of (very) short papers and exams.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Course Description: This course provides an advanced introduction to contemporary work on the mind-body problem. This is the problem of understanding the metaphysical relationship between the mental and the physical. Our discussion will be organized around the thesis of physicalism: the thesis that, in a sense to be made precise, everything is physical. We will begin by asking how best to formulate the thesis of physicalism, focusing on what the physicalist means by everything and what they mean by physical. Having done so, we will turn to the topic of mental causation. According to manyphysicalists, the reality of mental causation provides a powerful source of support for their position. Our goal will be to understand why they have thought this and assesswhether theyare right. After considering debates about mental causation, well turn to questions aboutmental content, i.e., the aboutness of mental states. We will consider some influential physicalist attempts to explain mental content as well as the principal challenges that have doggedphysicalistaccounts of mental content. From content, we turn finally toconsciousness. Here, wellconsiderthe arguments that contemporary dualists haveofferedfor believing that the existence of consciousness is inconsistent with physicalism,as well as the main ways physicalistshave attempted to rebut these dualist arguments. In the time that we have left, well examine some historically neglected views of the mind-body relationship that have been receiving increased attention recently. We'll discuss: mysterianism (the view that the relation betweenconsciousnessand the physical lies forever beyond the cognitive grasp of humans); illusionism (the view that consciousness is illusory); panpsychism (the view that mind or consciousness is somehow woven into the physical fabric of the cosmos); and even some varieties of idealism (the view that everything, including the physical cosmos, is a mental construction).

instances.text: PHIL_V 455-A_001 - Topics in the Philosophy of Cognitive Science (A)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
In the first part of this seminar, we will focus on two concepts fundamental to contemporary cognitive science: "representation" and "computation". This will set up the context in which we will, in the later part of the seminar, examine the traditional debate about empiricism versus rationalism about the architecture of the cognitive mind, and in particular, about concepts.

The format of the seminar will consist of lectures, students' presentations, and class discussion. The course grade will be assigned on the basis of class presentations, participation, and a term paper/project. Details TBA.

Apart from some additional auxiliary readings (TBA), we'll read good portions of these three books:

 Fred Dretske, (1981). Knowledge and the Flow of Information, MIT Press.
 Nicholas Shea, (2018). Representation in Cognitive Science, Oxford UP.
 Stephen Laurence and Eric Margolis, (2024). The Building Blocks of Thought, Oxford UP.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
